Johnny Cash (1932-2003) was a legendary American singer-songwriter, musician, and author who was known as "The Man in Black" for his distinctive deep voice and iconic black clothing. He was one of the most influential musicians of the 20th century, with a career spanning over 50 years.

Born J.R. Cash on February 26, 1932, in Kingsland, Arkansas, Johnny grew up in a poor family and developed a strong connection to music at an early age. He was heavily influenced by gospel and blues music, and began writing his own songs as a teenager.

In 1954, Johnny joined the United States Air Force, where he formed a music group with several fellow airmen. After his discharge, he began performing professionally, initially under the stage name John Cash. He signed with Sun Records in 1955 and released his debut single, "Hey Porter," which became a moderate success.

Johnny's breakthrough came in 1956 with the release of "I Walk the Line," a song he wrote for his future wife, Vivian Liberto. The song topped the country music charts and launched Johnny's career as a country music star. He went on to release a string of successful albums and singles, including "Folsom Prison Blues," "Get Rhythm," and "Guess Things Happen That Way."

In the 1960s, Johnny expanded his musical horizons, experimenting with rock, blues, and folk music. He collaborated with other artists, including Bob Dylan, Willie Nelson, and Neil Young, and released several critically acclaimed albums, including "At Folsom Prison" and "At San Quentin."

Johnny's music often dealt with themes of love, social justice, and redemption, and he became known for his powerful, emotive performances. He was also a prolific songwriter, penning over 1,000 songs throughout his career, including "Ring of Fire," "Man in Black," and "Sunday Mornin' Comin' Down."

Throughout his life, Johnny was open about his struggles with addiction and personal demons. He was married four times, including to country music star June Carter Cash, whom he married in 1968. The couple remained together until Johnny's death in 2003.

Johnny Cash was inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame, the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, and the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, among other honors. He was also awarded 11 Grammy Awards and a Kennedy Center Honor.
